==== Dal Khalsa ==== {{Main|Dal Khalsa (Sikh Empire)}} [[File:Dilruba detail.jpg|thumb|[[Ragi (Sikhism)|Ragi]]s recite [[Sikh scriptures]] alongside playing portable instruments such as the [[Dilruba]]]] The Khalsa reorganised themselves into two divisions, the younger generation would be part of the Taruna Dal, which provided the main fighting force, while the Sikhs above the age of forty years would be a part of the Budha Dal, which provided the responsibility of the management of Gurdwaras and [[Gurmat]] preaching.<ref>{{cite book|last=H. S. Singha|title=The Encyclopedia of Sikhism|year=2000|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=9788170103011|page=39}}</ref> The Budha Dal would be responsible to keep track of the movements of government forces, plan their defense strategies, and they provide a reserve fighting force for the Taruna Dal.<ref name="Singh 1927 16"/>
The following measures were established by Nawab Kapur Singh:<ref name="Singh 1927 17">{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=17}}</ref> * All money obtained from anywhere by any [[Jatha]] should be deposited in the Common Khalsa Fund. * The Khalsa should have their common [[Langar (Sikhism)|Langer]] for both the Dals. * Every Sikh should respect the orders of his [[Jathedar]]. Anyone going anywhere would get permission from him and report to him on his return.
==== 5 Sikh Misls of the Dal Khalsa ==== The Taruna Dal quickly increased to more than 12,000 recruits and it soon became difficult to manage the house and feeding of such a large number of people at one place.<ref name="Singh 1927 17"/> It was then decided to have five divisions of the Dal, each to draw rations from the central stocks and cook its own [[Langar (Sikhism)|langar]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Chhabra|first=G. S.|title=Advanced History of the Punjab, Volume 1|year=1968|publisher=New Academic Publishing Company|location=he University of Virginia|page=358}}</ref> These five divisions were stationed around the five sarovars (sacred pools) around [[Amritsar]] they were Ramsar, Bibeksar, Lachmansar, Kaulsar and Santokhsar.<ref>{{cite book|last=Nijjar|first=Bakhshish|title=Panjab Under the Later Mughals, 1707-1759|year=1972|publisher=New Academic Publishing Company|page=107}}</ref> The divisions later became known as [[Misl]]s and their number increased to eleven. Each took over and ruled a different region of the [[Punjab region|Punjab]]. Collectively they called themselves the [[Sarbat Khalsa]].
==== Preparing Jassa Singh Ahluwalia for leadership ====
Being the leader of the Khalsa [[Nawab Kapur Singh]] was given an additional responsibility by [[Mata Sundari]], the wife of [[Guru Gobind Singh]] sent Kapur Singh the young [[Jassa Singh Ahluwalia]] and told him that Ahluwalia was like a son to her and that the Nawab should raise him like an ideal Sikh. Ahluwalia under the guidance of Kapur Singh, was given a good education in [[Gurbani]] and a thorough training in managing the Sikh affairs.<ref name="Singh 1927 18">{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=18}}</ref> Later Jassa Singh Ahluwalia would become an important role in leading the Sikhs to self-rule.
==== State oppression ====
In 1735, the rulers of Lahore attacked and repossessed the [[jagir]] (estate) given to the Sikhs only two years before<ref>{{cite book|last=Singha|first=H.S.|title=Sikh Studies, Book 6|year=2005|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=9788170102588|page=30}}</ref> however [[Nawab Kapur Singh]] in reaction decided the whole [[Punjab region|Punjab]] should be taken over by the Sikhs.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Sangat|title=The Sikhs in History|year=1995|publisher=S. Singh|location=New York|page=99}}</ref> This decision was taken against heavy odds but was endorsed by the [[Khalsa]] and all the Sikhs assured him of their full cooperation in his endeavor for self-rule. [[Zakariya Khan Bahadur]] sent roaming squads to hunt and kill the Sikhs. Orders were issued to all administrators down to the village level officials to seek Sikhs, murder them, get them arrested, or report their whereabouts to the governments. One years wages were offered to anyone who would murder a Sikh and deliver his head to the police station.<ref name="Singh 1927 18"/> Rewards were also promised to those who helped arrest Sikhs. Persons providing food or shelter to Sikhs or helping them in any way were severely punished.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Teja|title=A Short History of the Sikhs: 1469-1765|year=1999|publisher=Publication Bureau, Punjabi University|location=Patiala|isbn=9788173800078|page=119}}</ref>
This was the period when the Sikhs were sawed into pieces,<ref>{{cite book |last=Sethi |first=Amarjit |title=Universal Sikhism |year=1972 |publisher=Hemkunt Press |location=The University of California |page=144}}</ref> burnt alive,<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Sikh Review |year=2005 |volume=53 |issue=7-12; 619-624 |page=52 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ObIlAQAAIAAJ |accessdate=2013-09-18}}</ref> their heads crushed with hammers<ref name="Singh 1927 19">{{cite book |last=Singh |first=Gurbaksh |title=The Khalsa Generals |year=1927 |publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society |isbn=0969409249 |page=19}}</ref> and young children were pierced with spears before their mother’s eyes.<ref>{{cite book |last=Randhawa |first=Ajit |title=Evolution of Faith and Religion: An Exploration |year=2009 |publisher=AuthorHouse |isbn=9781449000806 |page=238}}</ref> To keep their morale high, the Sikhs developed their own high-sounding terminologies and slogans:<ref name="Singh 1927 19"/> For example. Tree leaves boiled for food were called ‘green dish’; the parched [[chickpea]]s were called ‘almonds’; the [[Acacia nilotica|Babul tree]] was a ‘rose’; a blind man was a ‘brave man’, getting on the back of a [[Bovinae|buffalo]] was ‘riding an elephant’.
The army pursued the Sikhs hiding near the hills and forced them to cross the rivers and seek safety in the [[Malwa]] tract.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Harbans|title=The Heritage of the Sikh|year=1983|publisher=Manohar Publications|page=127}}</ref> When Kapur Singh reached [[Patiala district|Patiala]] he met [[Maharaja]] [[Maharaja of Patiala|Baba Ala Singh]] who then took [[Amrit Sanskar|Amrit]]<ref>{{cite book|last=H. S. Singha|title=The Encyclopedia of Sikhism|year=2000|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=9788170103011|page=15}}</ref> and Kapur Singh helped him increase the boundaries of his state. In 1736 the Khalsa attacked [[Sirhind]], where the two younger sons of [[Guru Gobind Singh]] were killed. The Khalsa took over the city, the took over the treasury and they established the [[Gurdwara]]s at the historical places and withdrew.<ref name="Singh 1927 19"/> While near [[Amritsar]] the government of Lahore sent troops to attack the Sikhs. Kapur Singh entrusted the treasury to [[Jassa Singh Ahluwalia]], while having sufficient amount of Sikhs with him to keep the army engaged. When Jassa Singh was reached a consider distance the Khalsa safely retreated to [[Tarn Taran Sahib]]. Kapur Singh sent messages to the Tauna Dal asking them to help them in the fight. After a days of fighting Kapur Singh from the trenches dug by the Khalsa surprisingly attacked the commanding posts killing three generals alongside many Mughal officers. The Mughal army thus retreated to Lahore.
Zakaria Khan called his advisers to plan another strategy to deal with the Sikhs. It was suggested that the Sikhs should not be allowed to visit the Amrit Sarovar,<ref name="Singha 2005 31">{{cite book|last=Singha|first=H.S.|title=Sikh Studies, Book 6|year=2005|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=9788170102588|page=31}}</ref> which was believed to be the fountain of their lives and source of their strength. Strong contingents were posted around the city and all entries to [[Harmandir Sahib]] were checked. The Sikhs, however, risking their lives, continued to pay their respects to the holy place and take a dip in the Sarovar (sacred pool) in the dark of the night. When Kapur Singh went to Amritsar he had a fight with [[Qadi]] Abdul Rehman. He had declared that Sikhs the so-called [[lions]], would not dare to come to Amritsar and face him. In the ensuing fight Abdul Rehman was killed.<ref>{{cite book|last=Surjit|first=Gandhi|title=Struggle of the Sikhs for sovereignty|year=1980|publisher=Gur Das Kapur|page=74}}</ref> When his son tried to save him, he too lost his life. In 1738 [[Bhai Mani Singh]] was executed.
==== Sikhs attack Nader Shah ==== In 1739 [[Nader Shah]] of the [[Turkic peoples|Turkic]] [[Afsharid dynasty]] invaded and looted the treasury of the [[Indian subcontinent]]. Nader Shah killed more than 100,000 people in Delhi and carried off all of the gold and valuables.<ref>{{cite book|last=Mitchell|first=Augustus|title=An accompaniment to Mitchell's map of the world|year=1840|publisher=R.L. Barnes|location=Harvard University|page=510}}</ref> He added to his caravan hundreds of elephants and horses, along with thousands of young women and Indian [[artisans]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Sikh Review|year=2005|volume=53|issue=1-6; 613-618|page=40 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9nXXAAAAMAAJ |accessdate=2013-09-18}}</ref> When [[Kapur Singh]] came to know of this, he decided to warn Nader Shah that if not the local rulers, then the Sikhs would protect the innocent women of Muslims and Hindus from being sold as slaves. While crossing The river [[Chenab]], the Sikhs attacked the rear end of the caravan, freed many of the women, freed the artisans, and recovered part of the treasure.<ref>{{cite book|last=Chhabra|first=G. S.|title=Advance Study in the History of Modern India (Volume-1: 1707-1803)|year=2005|publisher=Lotus Press|location=India|isbn=9788189093068|page=10}}</ref> The Sikhs continued to harass him and lighten him of his loot until he withdrew from the Punjab.
==== Sikhs kill Massa Rangar ====
[[Massa Ranghar]], the Mughal official, had taken over the control of [[Amritsar]]. While smoking and drinking in the [[Harmandir Sahib]], he watched the dances of [[nautch]] girls.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Parm|title=Golden Temple|year=1999|publisher=Publication Bureau, Punjabi University|isbn=9788173805691|page=4}}</ref> The Sikhs who had moved to [[Bikaner district|Bikaner]], a desert region, for safety, were outraged to hear of this desecration. In 1740 [[Sukha Singh]] and [[Mehtab Singh Bhangu|Mehtab Singh]], went to Amritsar disguised as revenue collectors.<ref>{{cite book|last=H. S. Singha|title=The Encyclopedia of Sikhism|year=2000|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=9788170103011|page=137}}</ref> They tied their horses outside, walked straight into the [[Harmandir Sahib]], cut off his head,<ref>{{cite book|last=Kohli|first=Surinder|title=The Sikh and Sikhism|year=1993|publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Distributors|page=60}}</ref> and took it with them. It was a lesson for the ruler that no tyrant would go unpunished.
==== Sikhs loot Abdus Samad Khan ====
Abdus Samad Khan, a senior Mughal royal commander, was sent from [[Delhi]] to subdue the Sikhs.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Harbans|title=The Heritage of the Sikhs|year=1964|publisher=Asia Publishing House|page=56}}</ref> Kapur Singh learned of this scheme and planned his own strategy accordingly. As soon as the army was sent out to hunt for the Sikhs, a [[Jatha]] of commandos disguised as messengers of Khan went to the [[Armory (military)|armory]]. The commander there was told that Abdus Samad Khan was holding the Sikhs under siege and wanted him with all his force to go and arrest them. The few guards left behind were then overpowered by the Sikhs, and all the arms and ammunition were looted and brought to the Sikh camp.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=21}}</ref>
==== Mughals increase persecution ====
Abdus Samad Khan sent many roaming squads to search for and kill Sikhs. He was responsible for the torture and murder of [[Bhai Mani Singh]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Jawandha|first=Nahar|title=Glimpses of Sikhism|year=2010|publisher=Sanbun Publishers|location=New Delhi|isbn=9789380213255|page=58}}</ref> the head [[Granthi]] of Harimander Sahib. Samad Khan was afraid that Sikhs would kill him so he remained far behind the fighting lines.<ref>{{cite book|last=Chhabra|first=G. S.|title=Advanced History of the Punjab, Volume 1|year=1968|publisher=New Academic Publishing Company|location=The University of Virginia|page=363}}</ref> Kapur Singh had a plan to get him. During the battle Kapur Singh ordered his men to retreat drawing the fighting army with them. He then wheeled around and fell upon the rear of the army.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Panjab Past and Present, Volume 11|year=1977|publisher=Department of Punjab Historical Studies, Punjabi University|location=The University of California|page=85}}</ref> Samad Khan and his guards were lying dead on the field within hours. The Punjab governor also took extra precautions for safety against the Sikhs. He started to live in the fort. He would not even dare to visit the mosque outside the fort for prayers.
On the request of the Budha Dal members, Kapur Singh visited [[Patiala]]. The sons of Sardar Ala Singh, the founder and [[Maharajah]] of the [[Patiala district|Patiala state]], gave him a royal welcome. Kapur Singh subdued all local administrators around Delhi who were not behaving well towards their people.
Zakaria Khan died in 1745. His successor tightened the security around [[Amritsar]]. Kapur Singh planned to break the siege of Amritsar. Jassa Singh Ahluwalia was made the commander of the attacking Sikh forces. In 1748, the Sikhs attacked. Jassa Singh Ahluwalia, with his commandos behind him, dashed to the army commander and cut him into two with his sword. The commander's nephew was also killed.
==== The Khalsa strengthen military developments ====
The Sikhs built their first fort Ram Rauni at Amritsar in 1748.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kaur|first=Madanjit|title=The Golden Temple: Past and Present|year=1983|publisher=Department of Guru Nanak Studies, Guru Nanak Dev University Press|location=The University of Michigan|page=43}}</ref> In December 1748, Governor Mir Mannu had to take his forces outside of [[Lahore]] to stop the advance of [[Ahmad Shah Abdali]]. The Sikhs quickly overpowered the police defending the station in Lahore and confiscated all of their weapons and released all the prisoners.<ref>{{cite book|last=Gill|first=Tarlochan|title=History of the Sikhs|year=1996|publisher=Canada Centre Publications|page=24}}</ref> Nawab Kapur Singh told the sheriff to inform the Governor that, the sheriff of God, the True Emperor, came and did what he was commanded to do. Before the policemen could report the matter to the authorities, or the army could be called in, the Khalsa were already riding their horses back to the forest.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=24}}</ref> Nawab Kapur Singh died in 1753.
=== Jassa Singh Ahluwalia === {{Main|Jassa Singh Ahluwalia}} [[File:PicKingRaja.jpg|thumb|[[Jassa Singh Ahluwalia]]]]
Jassa Singh Ahluwalia was born in 1718. His father, Badar Singh, died when Ahluwalia was only four years old.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jawandha|first=Nahar|title=Glimpses of Sikhism|publisher=Sanbun Publishers|isbn=9789380213255|page=209}}</ref> His mother took him to [[Mata Sundari]], the wife of [[Guru Gobind Singh]] when Ahluwalia was young.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dhamija|first=Sumant|title=The Lion Hearted Jassa Singh Ahluwalia of Punjab|journal=Indian Defence Review|year=2004|volume=25|series=2|page=87|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H6fqIFGD-E0C&dq=jassa+singh+Mata+Sundari&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Parm|title=Golden Temple|year=1999|publisher=Publication Bureau, Punjabi University|isbn=9788173805691|page=19}}</ref> Mata Sundri was impressed by his melodious singing of hymns and kept the Ahluwalia near her. Later Jassa Singh Ahluwalia was adopted by Nawab Kapoor Singh,<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Ganda|title=Sardar Jassa Singh Ahluwalia|year=1990|publisher=Publication Bureau, Punjabi University|page=32}}</ref> then the leader of the Sikh nation. Ahluwalia followed all Sikh qualities required for a leader Ahluwalia would sing [[Asa di Var]] in the morning and it was appreciated by all the [[Dal Khalsa (Sikh Empire)|Dal Khalsa]] and Ahluwalia kept busy doing [[Selfless service|seva]] (selfless service). He became very popular with the Sikhs. He used to tie his [[turban]] in the [[Mughal Empire|Mughal]] fashion as he grew up in Delhi. Ahluwalia learned [[Equestrianism|horseback riding]] and [[swordsmanship]] from expert teachers.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=25}}</ref>
In 1748 Jassa Singh Ahluwalia became the supreme commander of all the Misls.<ref name="H. S. Singha 2000 111">{{cite book|last=H. S. Singha|title=The Encyclopedia of Sikhism|year=2000|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=9788170103011|page=111}}</ref> Jassa Singh Ahluwalia was honored with the title of Sultanul Kaum (King of the Nation).<ref>{{cite book|last=Griffin|first=Lepel|title=The Panjab chiefs, historical and biographical notices|year=1865|publisher=Oxford University|page=172}}</ref> Jassa Singh Ahluwalia was the head of the Ahluwalia Misl and then after Nawab Kapoor Singh become the leader of all the Misls jointly called Dal Khalsa. He played a major role In leading the Khalsa to self-rule in [[Punjab, region|Punjab]]. In 1761 The Dal Khalsa under the leadership of Ahluwalia, would take over [[Lahore]], the capital of Punjab, for the first time.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singha|first=H.S.|title=Sikh Studies, Book 6|year=2005|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=9788170102588|page=39}}</ref> They were the masters of Lahore for a few months and minted their own Nanakshahi [[rupee]] coin in the name of 'Guru Nanak – Guru Gobind Singh'.<ref name="Singha 2000 111">{{cite book|last=Singha|first=H. S.|title=The Encyclopedia of Sikhism|year=2000|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=9788170103011|page=111}}</ref>
==== Chhota Ghalughara (The Lesser Massacre) ==== {{Main|Sikh holocaust of 1746}}
In 1746 about seven thousand Sikhs were killed and three thousand to fifteen thousand<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Sikh Review |year=2003|volume=51|issue=1-6; 589-594|page=40|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o3XXAAAAMAAJ |accessdate=2013-09-18}}</ref> Sikhs were taken prisoners during by the order of the [[Mughal Empire]] when Zakaria Khan, The Governor of Lahore, and Lakhpat Rai, the [[Divan]] (Revenue Minister) of Zakaria Khan, sent military squads to kill the Sikhs.<ref name="Kohli 1993 62">{{cite book |last=Kohli |first=Surinder |title=The Sikh and Sikhism |year=1993 |publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Distributors |page=62}}</ref><ref name="Mehta 2005 675">{{cite book |last=Mehta |first=Jaswant |title=Advanced Study in the History of Modern India: 1707 - 1813 |year=2005 |publisher=Sterling Publishers Pvt. Ltd |isbn=9781932705546 |page=675}}</ref>
Jaspat Rai, a [[jagir]]dar (landlord) of the [[Eminabad]] area and also the brother of Lakhpat Rai, faced the Sikhs in a battle one of the Sikhs held the tail of his elephant and got on his back from behind and with a quick move, he chopped off his head.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dilagir|first=Harajindar|title=The Sikh Reference Book|year=1997|publisher=Sikh Educational Trust for Sikh University Centre|location=Denmark|isbn=9780969596424|page=446}}</ref> Seeing their master killed, the troops fled. Lakhpat Rai, after this incident, committed himself to destroying the Sikhs.<ref name="Mehta 2005 675"/>
Through March–May 1746, a new wave of violence was started against the Sikhs with all of the resources available to the Mughal government, village officials were ordered to co-operate in the expedition. Zakaria Khan issued the order that no one was to give any help or shelter to Sikhs and warned that severe consequences would be taken against anyone disobeying these orders.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kapoor|first=Sukhbir|title=The Ideal Man: The Concept of Guru Gobind Singh, the Tenth Prophet of the Sikhs|year=1988|publisher=Khalsa College London Press|page=181}}</ref> Local people were forcibly employed to search for the Sikhs to be killed by the army. Lakhpat Rai ordered Sikh places of worship to be destroyed and their holy books burnt.<ref>{{cite book|last=Johar|first=Surinder|title=The Sikh Sword to Power|year=2002|publisher=Arsee Publishers|page=68}}</ref> Information about including Jassa Singh Ahluwalia and a large body of Sikhs were camping in riverbeds in the [[Gurdaspur district]] ([[Kahnuwan]] tract). Zakaria Khan managed to have 3,000 Sikhs of these Sikhs captured and later got them beheaded in batches at Nakhas (site of the horse market outside the Delhi gate).<ref>{{cite book|last=Kumar|first=Ram|title=The Sikh struggle: origin, evolution, and present phase|year=1991|publisher=Chanakya Publications|page=75}}</ref> Sikhs raised a memorial shrine known as the Shahidganj (the treasure house of martyrs) at that place latter.
In 1747, Shah Nawaz took over as Governor of Lahore. To please the Sikhs, Lakhpat Rai was put in prison by the new Governor.<ref name="Kohli 1993 62"/> Lakhpat Rai received severe punishment and was eventually killed by the Sikhs.
==== Reclaiming Amritsar ==== In 1747 Salabat Khan, a newly appointed Mughal commander, placed police around Amritsar and built observation posts to spot and kill Sikhs coming to the Amrit Sarovar for a holy dip.<ref name="Singha 2005 31"/> Jassa Singh Ahluwalia and Nawab Kapoor Singh led the Sikhs to Amritsar, and Salabat Khan was killed by Ahluwalia, and his nephew was killed by the arrow of Kapur Singh.<ref name="Singh 2007"/><ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=27}}</ref> The Sikhs restored Harmandir Sahib and celebrated their [[Bandi Chhor Divas|Diwali]] gathering there.
==== Reorganisation of the Misls ==== In 1748 all the Misls joined themselves under one command and on the advice of the aging [[Jathedar]] Nawab Kapoor Singh Jassa Singh Ahluwalia was made the supreme leader.<ref name="Singha 2000 111"/> They also decided to declare that the Punjab belonged to them and they would be the sovereign rulers of their state. The Sikhs also built their first fort, called Ram Rauni, at [[Amritsar]].
==== Khalsa side with the Government ==== [[Adina Beg]], the [[Faujdar]] (garrison commander) of [[Jalandhar district|Jalandhar]], sent a message to the [[Dal Khalsa (Sikh Empire)|Dal Khalsa]] chief to cooperate with him in the civil administration, and he wanted a meeting to discuss the matter.<ref>{{cite book|last=Markovit|first=Claude|title=A History of Modern India: 1480 - 1950|year=2002|publisher=Anthem Press|isbn=9781843310044|page=199}}</ref> This was seen as a trick to disarm the Sikhs and keep them under government control. Jassa Singh Ahluwalia replied that their meeting place would be the battle ground and the discussion would be carried out by their swords. Beg attacked the Ram Rauni fort at Amritsar and besieged the Sikhs there.<ref>{{cite book|last=H. S. Singha|title=The Encyclopedia of Sikhism|year=2000|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=9788170103011|page=10}}</ref> Dewan Kaura Mal advised the Governor to lift the siege and prepare the army to protect the state from the Durrani invader, Ahmed Shah Abdali. Kaura Mal had a part of the revenue of Patti area given to the Sikhs for the improvement and management of Harmandir Sahib, Amritsar.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Khushwant|title=A History of the Sikhs: 1469-1839|year=1963|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=134}}</ref>
Kaura Mal had to go to [[Multan]] to quell a rebellion there. He asked the Sikhs for help and they agreed to join him. After the victory at Multan, Kaura came to pay his respects to the [[Harmandir Sahib|Darbar Sahib]], and offered 11,000 rupees and built Gurdwara Bal-Leela; He also spent 3,000,000 rupees to build a Sarover (holy water) at [[Nankana Sahib]], the birthplace of Guru Nanak Dev.<ref>{{cite book|last=Tasneem|first=Niranjan|title=The Lost Meaning|year=2006|publisher=Sahitya Akademi|isbn=9788126017966|page=153}}</ref> In 1752, Kaura Mall was killed in a battle with Ahmed Shah Abdali and state policy towards the Sikhs quickly changed. Mir Mannu, the Governor, started hunting Sikhs again. He arrested many men and women, put them in prison and tortured them. In November 1753,{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} when he went to kill the Sikhs hiding in the fields, they showered him with a hail of bullets and Mannu fell from the horse and the animal dragged him to death. The Sikhs immediately proceeded to Lahore, attacked the prison, and got all the prisoners released and led them to safety in the forests.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=29}}</ref>
==== Harmandir Sahib demolished in 1757 ==== In May 1757, the [[Afghan]] [[Durrani Empire|Durrani]] general of [[Ahmad Shah Abdali]], Jahan Khan attacked Amritsar with a huge army and the Sikhs because of their small numbers decided to withdraw to the forests. Their fort, Ram Rauni, was demolished,{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} [[Harmandir Sahib]] was also demolished, and the army desecrated the Sarovar (Holy water) by filling it with debris and dead animals.<ref>{{cite book|last=Mehta|first=Jaswant|title=Advanced Study in the History of Modern India: 1707 - 1813|year=2005|publisher=Sterling Publishers Pvt. Ltd|isbn=9781932705546|page=256}}</ref> [[Baba Deep Singh]] made history when he cut through 20,000 Durrani soldiers and reached Harmandir Sahib, Amritsar.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singha|first=H.S.|title=Sikh Studies, Book 7|year=2005|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=9788170102458|page=36}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Johar|first=Surinder|title=The Sikh Sword to Power|year=2002|publisher=Arsee Publishers|location=The University of Michigan|page=88}}</ref>
==== The Khalsa gain territory ==== [[File:River Beas.jpg|thumb|Beas Rivers]] [[Adina Beg]] did not pay revenues to the government so the Governor dismissed him<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Diwan|title=The Revolution of Guru Nanak|year=1993|publisher=Peoples Publishing House|page=186}}</ref> and appointed a new [[Faujdar]] (garrison commander) in his place. The army was sent to arrest him and this prompted Adina Beg to request Sikh help. The Sikhs took advantage of the situation and to weaken the government, they fought against the army. One of the commanders was killed by the Sikhs and the other deserted. Later, the Sikhs attacked [[Jalandhar]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Dhavan|first=Purnima|title=When Sparrows Became Hawks: The Making of the Sikh Warrior Tradition, 1699-1799|year=2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199756551|page=91}}</ref> and thus became the rulers of all the tracts between [[Sutlej]] and [[Beas River|Beas]] rivers, called [[Doaba]].<ref name="Singh 1927 33">{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=33}}</ref> Instead of roaming in the forests now they were ruling the cities.
The Sikhs started bringing more areas under their control and realising revenue from them. In 1758, joined by the [[Maratha Empire|Mahrattas]],<ref>{{cite book|last=A. H.|first=Bingley|title=Sikhs|year=1970|publisher=Department of Languages, Punjab|location=The University of Michigan|page=27}}</ref> they conquered Lahore and arrested many Afghan soldiers who were responsible for filling the Amrit Sarovar with debris a few months earlier. They were brought to Amritsar and made to clean the Sarovar (holy water).<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Sikh Courier International |year=1985 |volume=25; 27 |issue=60; 64 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OWJRAAAAYAAJ |accessdate=2013-09-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Sobati|first=Haracaran|title=The Sikh Psyche: A Study of the Fictional Writings of Bhai Vir Singh|year=1990|publisher=Eastern Book Linkers|isbn=9788185133423|page=64}}</ref> After the cleaning of the Sarovar, the soldiers were allowed to go home with a warning that they should not do that again.
[[Ahmed Shah Abdali]] came again in October 1759 to loot Delhi. The Sikhs gave him a good fight and killed more than 2,000 of his soldiers. Instead of getting involved with the Sikhs, he made a rapid advance to Delhi. The Khalsa decided to collect revenues from Lahore to prove to the people that the Sikhs were the rulers of the state. The Governor of Lahore closed the gates of the city and did not come out to fight against them. The Sikhs laid siege to the city. After a week, the Governor agreed to pay 30,000 [[rupee]]s to the Sikhs.
Ahmed Shah Abdali returned from Delhi in March 1761 with lots of gold and more than 2,000 young girls as prisoners who were to be sold to the Afghans in Kabul. When Abdali was crossing the river Beas, the Sikhs swiftly fell upon them. They freed the women prisoners and escorted them back to their homes. The Sikhs took over Lahore in September of 1761, after Abdali returned to [[Kabul]].
The Khalsa minted their coins in the name of [[Guru Nanak Dev]]. Sikhs, as rulers of the city, received full cooperation from the people. After becoming the Governor of Lahore, Punjab Jassa Singh Ahluwalia was given the title of [[Sultan]]-ul-[[Qaum|Kaum]] (King of the Nation).<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Patwant|title=The Sikhs|year=2007|publisher=Random House Digital, Inc.|isbn=9780307429339}}</ref>
==== Wadda Ghalughara (The Great Massacre) ==== {{Main|Sikh holocaust of 1762}} In the winter of 1762, after losing his loot from Delhi to the Sikhs, The [[Durrani]] emperor, [[Ahmad Shah Abdali]] brought a big, well equipped army to finish the Sikhs forever. Sikhs were near [[Ludhiana]] on their way to the forests and dry areas of the south and Abdali moved from Lahore very quickly and caught the Sikhs totally unprepared.<ref>{{cite book|last=Rashid|first=Haroon|title=History of the Pathans, Volume 1|year=2002|publisher=Haroon Rashid|page=166}}</ref> They had their women, children and old people with them. As many as 30,000 Sikhs are said to have been murdered by the army.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bigelow|first=Anna|title=Sharing the Sacred: Practicing Pluralism in Muslim North India|year=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195368239|page=69}}</ref><ref name="Mayel 2006 58">{{cite book|last=Mayel|first=Jaspal|title=Universality of the Sikh Religion|year=2006|publisher=Jaspal Mayell|isbn=9780977790708|page=58}}</ref> Jassa Singh Ahluwalia himself received about two dozen wounds. Fifty chariots were necessary to transport the heads of the victims to Lahore.<ref>{{cite book|last=Markovitz|first=Claude|title=A History of Modern India: 1480 - 1950|year=2002|publisher=Anthem Press|isbn=9781843310044|page=1999}}</ref> The Sikhs call this [[Wadda Ghalughara]] (The Great Massacre).
==== Harmandir Sahib blown up in 1762 ====
[[Ahmad Shah Abdali]], fearing Sikh retaliation, sent messages that he was willing to assign some areas to the Sikhs to be ruled by them. [[Jassa Singh Ahluwalia]] rejected his offers and told him that Sikhs own the Punjab and they do not recognise his authority at all. Abdali went to Amritsar and destroyed the [[Harmandir Sahib]] again by filling it up with gunpowder hoping to eliminate the source of "life" of the Sikhs.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nevile|first=Pran|journal=India Perspectives|year=2004|volume=17|page=41}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Dhavan|first=Purnima|title=When Sparrows Became Hawks: The Making of the Sikh Warrior Tradition, 1699-1799|year=2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199756551|page=112}}</ref> While Abdali was demolishing the Harminder Sahib a he was hit on the nose with a brick;<ref>{{cite book|last=Johar|first=Surinder|title=The Heritage of Amritsar|year=1978|publisher=Sundeep Prakashan|location=University of Michigan|page=69}}</ref> later in 1772 Abdali died of cancer from the 'gangrenous ulcer' that consumed his nose.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dalrymple|first=William|title=Return of a King: The Battle for Afghanistan, 1839-42|year=2013|publisher=Random House Digital, Inc|isbn=9780307958297}}</ref> Within a few months the Sikhs attacked [[Sirhind]] and moved to Amritsar.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
==== Sikhs retake Lahore ==== In 1764 the Sikhs shot dead [[Zain Khan Sirhindi]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Parm|title=Golden Temple|year=1999|publisher=Publication Bureau, Punjabi University|isbn=9788173805691|page=15}}</ref> Durrani Governor of Sirhind, and the regions around Sirhind were divided among the Sikh [[Misl]]dars and money recovered from the treasury were used to rebuild the [[Harmandir Sahib]]. [[Gurdwara Fatehgarh Sahib]] was built in Sirhind, at the location the two younger sons of [[Guru Gobind Singh]] were killed. The Sikhs started striking Govind Shahi coins<ref>{{cite book|last=Sen|first=S. N.|title=History Modern India|year=2006|publisher=New Age International|isbn=9788122417746|page=10}}</ref> and in 1765 they took over [[Lahore]] again.<ref>{{cite book|last=Grewal|first=Jaspal|title=The Sikhs of the Punjab|year=1998|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521637640|page=246}}</ref>
In 1767 when [[Ahmed Shah Abdali]] came again he sent messages to the Sikhs for their cooperation. He offered them the governorship of Punjab but was rejected.<ref name="Singh 1927 33"/> The Sikhs using repeated guerrilla attacks took away his caravan of 1,000 camels loaded with fruits from Kabul.<ref>{{cite book|last=Seetal|first=Sohan|title=Rise of the Sikh Power and Maharaja Ranjeet Singh|year=1971|publisher=Dhanpat Rai|location=The University of Michigan|page=46}}</ref> The Sikhs were again in control of the areas between [[Sutlej]] and [[Ravi River|Ravi]]. After Abdali’s departure to Kabul, Sikhs crossed the Sutlej and brought Sirhind and other areas right up to Delhi, the entire Punjab under their control.<ref name="Mayel 2006 58"/>
[[Shah Alam II]], the Mughal Emperor of Delhi was staying away in [[Allahabad]], ordered his commander Zabita Khan to fight the Sikhs.<ref name="Singh 1927 33"/> Zabita made a truce with them instead<ref>{{cite book|last=Umar|first=Muhammad|title=Muslim society in northern India during the eighteenth century|year=1998|page=533}}</ref> and then was dismissed from Alam’s service. Zabita Khan then became a Sikh and was given a new name, Dharam Singh.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jawandha|first=Nahar|title=Glimpses of Sikhism|year=2010|publisher=Sanbun Publishers|location=New Delhi|isbn=9789380213255|page=207}}</ref>
Qadi Nur Mohammed, who came to Punjab with Ahmad Shah Abdali and was present during many Sikh battles writes about the Sikhs:<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=34}}</ref> {{cquote|They do not kill a woman, a child, or a coward running away from the fight. They do not rob any person nor do they take away the ornaments of a woman, be she a queen or a slave girl. They commit no [[adultery]], rather they respect the women of even their enemies. They always shun thieves and adulterers and in [[generosity]] they surpass [[Hatim al-Tai|Hatim]]."}}
==== Peace in Amritsar ==== [[File:Red Fort.jpg|thumb|In 1783 the [[Sikh]]s capture the [[Red Fort]], Delhi]] [[Ahmad Shah Abdali]], fearing the Sikhs, did not follow his normal route through Punjab while he returned to Kabul. Jassa Singh Ahluwalia did not add more areas to his [[Misl]]. Instead, whenever any wealth or villages came into the hands of the Sikhs he distributed them among the [[Jathedar]]s of all the Misls. Ahluwalia passed his last years in [[Amritsar]]. With the resources available to him, he repaired all the buildings, improved the management of the Gurdwaras, and provided better civic facilities to the residents of Amritsar. He wanted every Sikh to take [[Amrit Sanskar|Amrit]] before joining the [[Dal Khalsa (Sikh Empire)|Dal Khalsa]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=35}}</ref>
Ahluwalia died in 1783 and was cremated near Amritsar. There is a city block, Katra Ahluwalia, in Amritsar named after him. This block was assigned to his Misl in honor of his having stayed there and protected the city of Amritsar.
=== Jassa Singh Ramgarhia === {{Main|Jassa Singh Ramgarhia}} [[File:BungaTowers.jpg|thumb|[[Ramgarhia Bunga]] built by Jassa Singh Ramgarhia in the late 18th century (year 1755)]] Jassa Singh Ramgarhia played an active role in Jassa Singh Alhuwalia’s army. He founded the Ramgarhia Misl<ref name="Duggal 2001 46">{{cite book|last=Duggal|first=Kartar|title=Maharaja Ranjit Singh: The Last to Lay Arms|year=2001|publisher=Abhinav Publications|isbn=9788170174103|page=46}}</ref> and played a major role in the battles of the [[Khalsa Panth]]. He suffered about two dozen wounds during the [[Wadda Ghalughara]]. Jassa Singh Ramgarhia was the son of Giani Bhagwan Singh<ref name="Duggal 2001 46"/> and was born in 1723. They lived in the village of Ichogil, near Lahore. His grandfather took [[Amrita|Amrit]] during the lifetime of Guru Gobind Singh,<ref name="Singh 1927 36">{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=36}}</ref> and joined him in many battles; he joined the forces of Banda Singh Bahadur. Ramgarhia was the oldest of five brothers. When Ramgarhia was young he had memorised [[Nitnem]] hymns and took Amrit.<ref name="Singh 1927 36"/>
==== Award of an Estate ==== In 1733, Zakaria Khan, the Governor of Punjab, needed help to protect himself from the Iranian invader, [[Nader Shah]]. He offered the Sikhs an estate and a royal robe.<ref>{{cite book|last=Markovitz|first=Claude|title=A History of Modern India: 1480 - 1950|year=2002|publisher=Anthem Press|isbn=9781843310044|page=198}}</ref> The Sikhs in the name of [[Nawab Kapur Singh|Kapur Singh]] accepted it. After the battle Zakaria Khan gave five villages to the Sikhs in reward for the bravery of Giani Bhagwan Singh, father of Ramgarhia, who died in the battle. Village Vallah was awarded to Ramgarhia,<ref>{{cite book|last=Dilagir|first=Harajindar|title=The Sikh Reference Book|year=1997|publisher=Sikh Educational Trust for Sikh University Centre|location=Denmark|isbn=9780969596424|page=447}}</ref> where Ramgarhia gained the administrative experience required to become a [[Jathedar]] (leader) of the Sikhs. During this period of peace with the government, the Sikhs built their fort, Ram Rauni, in Amritsar. Zakaria died in 1745 and [[Mir Mannu]] became the Governor of Lahore.
==== Jassa Singh honored as Jassa Singh Ramgarhia ====
[[Mir Mannu]] (Mu'in ul-Mulk), the Governor of Lahore, was worried about the increasing power of the Sikhs so he broke the peace. Mir Mannu also ordered [[Adina Beg]], the [[Faujdar]] (garrison commander) of the [[Jalandhar district|Jalandhar]] region, to begin killing the Sikhs.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=37}}</ref> Adina Beg was a very smart politician and wanted the Sikhs to remain involved helping them. In order to develop good relations with the Sikhs, he sent secret messages to them who were living in different places. [[Jassa Singh Ramgarhia]] responded and agreed to cooperate with the Faujdar and was made a Commander.<ref name="H. S. Singha 2000 111"/> This position helped him develop good relations with [[Divan]] Kaura Mal at Lahore and assign important posts to the Sikhs in the [[Jalandhar district|Jalandhar]] division.
The Governor of Lahore ordered an attack on Ram Rauni to kill the Sikhs staying in that fort. Adina Beg was required to send his army as well and Jassa Singh, being the commander of the Jalandhar forces, had to join the army to kill the Sikhs in the fort.<ref>{{cite book|last=Surjit|first=Gandhi|title=Struggle of the Sikhs for sovereignty|year=1980|publisher=Gur Das Kapur|page=316}}</ref> After about four months of siege, Sikhs ran short of food and supplies in the fort. He contacted the Sikhs inside the fort and joined them. Jassa Singh used the offices of Divan Kaura Mal and had the siege lifted.<ref name=Singh_2006_2>{{cite book | last=Singh | first=Khushwant | authorlink=Khushwant Singh | year=2006 | title=The Illustrated History of the Sikhs | publisher=Oxford University Press | location=India | isbn = 0-19-567747-1 | pages=60}} Also, as according to the Purātan Janamsākhī (the birth stories of Nanak).</ref> The fort was strengthened and named Ramgarh; Jassa Singh Ramgarhia, having been designated the [[Jathedar]] of the fort, became popular as Ramgarhia.
==== Fighting the tyrannical Government ==== [[Mir Mannu]] intensified his violence and oppression against the Sikhs. There were only 900 Sikhs when he surrounded the Ramgarh fort again.<ref>{{cite book|last=H. S. Singha|title=The Encyclopedia of Sikhism|year=2000|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=9788170103011|page=146}}</ref> The Sikhs fought their way out bravely through thousands of army soldiers. The army demolished the fort. The hunt for and torture of the Sikhs continued until Mannu died in 1753. Mannu's death left [[Punjab region|Punjab]] without any effective Governor. It was again an opportune period for the Sikhs to organise themselves and gain strength. [[Jassa Singh Ramgarhia]] rebuilt the fort and took possession of some areas around [[Amritsar]]. The Sikhs took upon themselves the task of protecting the people in the villages from the invaders.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=38}}</ref> The money they obtained from the people was called Rakhi (protection charges). The new Governor, [[Timur Shah Durrani|Taimur]], son of [[Ahmed Shah Abdali]], despised the Sikhs. In 1757, he again forced the Sikhs to vacate the fort and move to their hiding places. The fort was demolished, [[Harmandir Sahib]] was blown up, and [[Amrita|Amrit]] Sarovar was filled with debris.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} The Governor decided to replace [[Adina Beg]]. Beg asked the Sikhs for help and they both got a chance to weaken their common enemy. Adina Beg won the battle and became the Governor of Punjab. Sikhs rebuilt their fort Ramgarh and repaired the Harmandir Sahib. Beg was well acquainted with the strength of the Sikhs and he feared they would oust him if he allowed them to grow stronger, so he led a strong army to demolish the fort.<ref>{{cite book|last=Mehta|first=Jaswant|title=Advanced Study in the History of Modern India: 1707 - 1813|year=2005|publisher=Sterling Publishers Pvt. Ltd|isbn=9781932705546|page=257}}</ref> After fighting valiantly, the Sikhs decided to leave the fort. Adina Beg died in 1758.
==== Ramgarhia Misl Estate ==== [[File:Jodhsinghr.jpg|thumb|left|[[Jodh Singh Ramgarhia]] the son of [[Jassa Singh Ramgarhia]]]]
[[Jassa Singh Ramgarhia]] occupied the area to the north of Amritsar between the [[Ravi River|Ravi]] and the [[Beas River|Beas]] rivers.<ref>{{cite book|title=Punjab District Gazetteers: Supplement|year=1980|publisher=Controller of Print. and Stationery|page=37|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kBRuAAAAMAAJ |accessdate=2013-09-18}}</ref> He also added the [[Jalandhar district|Jalandhar]] region and [[Kangra district|Kangra]] hill areas to his estate. He had his capital in [[Sri Hargobindpur]], a town founded by the sixth Guru. The large size of Ramgarhia's territory aroused the jealousy of the other Sikh [[Misl]]s.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=40}}</ref>
==== Conflicts between Misls ==== A conflict between [[Kanhaiya Misl|Jai Singh Kanhaiya]] and Jassa Singh Ramgarhia developed and the [[Bhangi Misl]] sardars also developed differences with Jai Singh Kanhaiya. A big battle was fought between Jai Singh, [[Charat Singh]], and Jassa Singh Ahluwalia on one side and Bhangis, Ramgarhias and their associates on the other side. The Bhangi side lost the battle.
Later, Jassa Singh Ahluwalia, one day while hunting, happened to enter Ramgarhia territory where Jassa Singh Ramgarhia's brother arrested him. Ramgarhia apologised for the misbehaviour of his brother, and returned Ahluwalia with gifts.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dhavan|first=Purnima|title=When Sparrows Became Hawks: The Making of the Sikh Warrior Tradition, 1699-1799|year=2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199756551|page=85}}</ref>
==== Mutual Misl wars ====
Due to mutual jealousies, fights continued among the Sikh [[Sardar]]s. In 1776, the [[Bhangi Misl|Bhangis]] changed sides and joined Jai Singh Kanhaiya to defeat Jassa Singh Ramgarhia.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=R. N.|title=Historical Development of Sikhism: Religion to Politics|year=2003|publisher=Commonwealth Publishers|isbn=9788171697038|page=105}}</ref> His capital at [[Sri Hargobindpur]] was taken over and he was followed from village to village,<ref name="Singh 1927 41">{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=41}}</ref> and finally forced to vacate all his territory. He had to cross the river [[Sutlej]] and go to [[Maharaja of Patiala|Amar Singh]], the ruler of [[Patiala]]. Maharaja Amar Singh welcomed Ramgarhia and who then occupied the areas of Hansi and Hissar<ref>{{cite book|title=Punjab District Gazetteers: Supplement|year=1980|publisher=Controller of Print. and Stationery|page=38|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kBRuAAAAMAAJ |accessdate=2013-09-18}}</ref> which eventually Ramgarhia handed over to his son, [[Jodh Singh Ramgarhia]].
Maharaja Amar Singh and Ramgarhia took control of the villages on the west and north of Delhi, now forming parts of [[Haryana]] and Western [[Uttar Pradesh]]. The Sikhs disciplined and brought to justice all the Nawabs who were harassing their non-Muslim population. Jassa Singh Ramgarhia entered Delhi in 1783. [[Shah Alam II]], the Mughal emperor, extended the Sikhs a warm welcome.<ref name="Singh 1927 41"/> Ramgarhia left Delhi after receiving gifts from him. Because of the differences arising out of the issue of dividing the [[Jammu district|Jammu state]] revenues, long time friends and neighbors [[Maha Singh]], [[Jathedar]] of [[Sukerchakia Misl]] and [[Jai Singh Kanheya|Jai Singh]], Jathedar of the [[Kanheya Misl]], became enemies. This resulted in a war which changed the course of Sikh history. Maha Singh requested Ramgarhia to help him. In the battle, Jai Singh lost his son, Gurbalchsh Singh, while fighting with [[Ramgarhia]]s.
==Sikhs captured Delhi== {{see also|Sikh Occupation of Delhi and Red Fort}} After continuous raids, Sikhs under [[Baghel Singh]] defeated the mughals on 11 March 1783, captured Delhi and hoisted Sikh flag ([[Nishan Sahib]]) in Red Fort.
=== The creation of the United Misl ===
[[File:Ranjitsingh.gif|right|150px|thumb|[[Maharaja]] [[Ranjit Singh]]]]
[[Jai Singh Kanheya]]’s widowed daughter-in-law, [[Sada Kaur]], though very young, was a great statesperson. Sada Kaur saw the end of the Khalsa power through such mutual battles but she was able to convince [[Maha Singh]] to adopt the path of friendship.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dogra|first=R. C.|title=Encyclopaedia of Sikh Religion and Culture|year=1995|publisher=Vikas Publishing House|isbn=9780706983685|page=401}}</ref> For this she offered the hand of her daughter, then only a child, to his son, [[Ranjit Singh]] (later the Maharaja of the Punjab), who was then just a boy. The balance of power shifted in favour of this united [[Misl]]. This made Ranjit Singh the leader of the most powerful union of the Misls.
When the Afghan invader, [[Zaman Shah Durrani]], came in 1788 the Sikhs, however, were still divided. [[Ramgarhia]] and [[Bhangi Misl]]s were not willing to help Ranjit Singh to fight the invader, so the Afghans took over Lahore and looted it. Ranjit Singh occupied Lahore in 1799<ref>{{cite book|last=Chilana|first=Rajwant|title=International Bibliography of Sikh Studies|year=2005|publisher=Springer|isbn=9781402030437|page=218}}</ref> but still the Ramgarhias and Bhangis did not accept him as the leader of all the Sikhs. They got the support of their friends and marched to Lahore to challenge Ranjit Singh. When the Bhangi leader died Jassa Singh Ramgarhia returned to his territory.<ref>{{cite book|last=Singh|first=Gurbaksh|title=The Khalsa Generals|year=1927|publisher=Canadian Sikh Study & Teaching Society|isbn=0969409249|page=42}}</ref> Ramgarhia was eighty years old when he died in 1803. His son, [[Jodh Singh Ramgarhia]], developed good relations with Ranjit Singh and they never fought again.
